Error t value Pr(>|t|) ## (Intercept) 0.633885 0.003453 183.594 < 2e-16 *** ## fossil_fuel -0.312049 0.096912 -3.220 0.00129 ** ## nuclear 0.526021 0.055681 9.447 < 2e-16 *** ## renew 0.838740 0.125999 6.657 3.1e-11 *** ## --- ## Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ## ## Residual standard error: 0.2379 on 5066 degrees of freedom ## Multiple R-squared: 0.05147, Adjusted R-squared: 0.05091 ## F-statistic: 91.63 on 3 and 5066 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 5.2 What characterises the countries that have the most renewable energy mix? (There is no data on renewable energy available for 91 countries. These countries are mainly in Africa.) ## # A tibble: 16 x 3 ## energy value name ## <chr> <dbl> <chr> ## 1 biofuel 0 Top Ten ## 2 coal 9.61 Top Ten ## 3 gas 12.7 Top Ten ## 4 hydro 23.5 Top Ten ## 5 nuclear 1.85 Top Ten ## 6 oil 43.1 Top Ten ## 7 solar 0.377 Top Ten ## 8 wind 3.22 Top Ten ## 9 biofuel 0.464 Rest average ## 10 coal 15.0 Rest average ## 11 gas 31.5 Rest average ## 12 hydro 5.63 Rest average ## 13 nuclear 4.17 Rest average ## 14 oil 38.7 Rest average ## 15 solar 0.882 Rest average ## 16 wind 2.09 Rest average 5.2.1 Ideas: relationship between HDI and different energy metrics -> per capita, coal, renewable, etc. outlier analysis filter on GDP or population to make trends appear cluster countries by energy mix development of different income areas On the other hand, how does the production of coal and gas energy leading to more pollution might foster and hinder human development at the same time? - countries might consume other energy than they produce -
